user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCONF) && \
  (defined(HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_ONLN) || defined(HAS_DECL__SC_NPROC_ONLN))
  long value = -1;
#ifdef HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_ONLN
  if (0 >= value)
    value = sysconf (_SC_NPROCESSORS_ONLN);
#endif /* HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_ONLN */
#ifdef HAS_DECL__SC_NPROC_ONLN
  if (0 >= value)
    value = sysconf (_SC_NPROC_ONLN);
#endif /* HAS_DECL__SC_NPROC_ONLN */
  if (0 >= value)
    return -1;
  ret = (int) value;
  if ((long) ret != value)
    return -1; /* Overflow */
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCONF &&
          (HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_ONLN || HAS_DECL__SC_NPROC_ONLN) */
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
value = sysconf (_SC_NPROCESSORS_ONLN);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The function mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_ calls the POSIX library function sysconf(_SC_NPROCESSORS_ONLN). This is an external system/library call, not a call to itself (no direct recursion) and there is no evidence of an indirect recursive path in the provided code. Therefore Rule 17.2 is not violated.
